title: Barefoot in the Park
descriptions:
Barefoot in the Park (1967) is a romantic comedy about the exhilarating highs and awkward growing pains of newlywed life in New York City. After a whirlwind courtship, free-spirited Corie Bratter and her cautious, buttoned-up husband Paul move into their first apartment—a tiny top-floor walk-up in a Greenwich Village brownstone. The place is charming in theory and chaotic in practice: there’s a skylight with a hole, no closet space, a stuck heating system, and a daunting flight of stairs that leaves every visitor breathless. Corie sees adventure; Paul sees hazards.

Corie, eager to launch their married life with flair, embraces their bohemian surroundings, befriending the eccentric upstairs neighbor, Victor Velasco, an older, flamboyant charmer who lives by his wits and has a talent for turning inconveniences into romance. Paul, a young, conservative lawyer, struggles to reconcile Corie’s impulsiveness with his own practical sensibilities. Their differences, once adorable, begin to fray their patience: Corie wants spontaneity and romance; Paul wants stability and order.

In an attempt to prove that Paul can loosen up and that her mother, Ethel Banks, can open herself to new experiences, Corie arranges a double date with Velasco. The evening devolves into a hilariously misadventurous night on the town, capped by an exotic Albanian restaurant and a wild trek through the city in winter. Ethel, out of her depth yet game, finds herself both flustered and intrigued by Velasco’s flamboyance, while Paul is miserable—cold, uncomfortable, and acutely aware of everything going wrong.

The aftermath brings simmering tensions to a boil. Corie accuses Paul of being stuffy and unromantic; Paul counters that Corie is reckless and unrealistic. Small domestic irritations—a broken heater, snow coming through the skylight, the absence of a phone—become symbols of deeper differences in temperament. In a heated argument, Corie even suggests they might have made a mistake getting married. Paul, hurt and exhausted, retreats, and Corie considers separating, doubling down on her vision of a life lived “barefoot in the park,” without inhibitions or caution.

Ethel, caught between loyalty to her daughter and empathy for Paul, becomes an unlikely mediator. She sees that Corie’s idealism masks inexperience, while Paul’s rigidity hides genuine affection. Velasco, in his offbeat way, also nudges them toward perspective, reminding them that love requires both courage and compromise.

The crisis culminates when Paul, drunk and shivering, tries to prove he can be spontaneous by wandering the park without his shoes on a frigid night—embracing Corie’s metaphor in the most literal, hapless way. Corie, realizing the extent of his effort and her own stubbornness, rushes out in alarm. The couple’s reconciliation is tender and comic: they acknowledge that their differences are not fatal flaws but complementary strengths, and that marriage means meeting in the middle—sometimes with a little heat in the apartment and sometimes with a little barefoot dancing.

By the end, practical repairs and emotional mending align. The skylight is fixed, the phone works, and Ethel tentatively explores a connection with Velasco, hinting that love may yet surprise at any age. Corie and Paul, still themselves but wiser, recommit to making their marriage work: she will find room for responsibility; he will make space for spontaneity. The final image celebrates their renewed bond—imperfect, spirited, and undeniably alive—capturing the film’s central message that love flourishes when partners learn to walk barefoot together, even if the park is cold.
